meeting_annotations.transcript: There are challenges too right because I do think obviously the trainees need to be heard but there are also biases and so you know particularly for women I think that can be a very contentious issue no matter what. meeting_annotations.speaker: Lydia Kisley
meeting_annotations.transcript: Also I feel like in this hypothetical you have to trust that the department or the tenure committee will take those things seriously. meeting_annotations.speaker: Caitlin Davis
meeting_annotations.transcript: So in our department we have mentoring statements for all of the faculty members that incoming students get and we were given directions and every faculty member decided how much of those directions that they wanted to follow and so I think that's a way to be kind of transparent about mentoring styles of of different faculty. So.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alison Ondrus
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think too like advancing student groups is also really important because often times as you know Alice pointed out it's not necessarily the right relationship to be mentoring students on like the different stages that they're personally experiencing from an advisor point of view because of the power dynamic and because of the different stages that one's at in one's scientific career. Sometimes I've found personally that like student support groups can be very effective at at being able to navigate some of the specific tensions and issues that students are encountering at a certain place in their career. But I think the other the other point that I was going to bring up is just you know all of the things that we were talking about the topics of of stress and expectations and sort of conformism if that's a thing is really kind of limiting the creativity of of students I think and I think that's really a crisis for science right now because even I think there was like potentially a time when there was a lot more freedom and just sort of individual just passion for something that may or may not have been recognized but when you're at a certain stage you don't know what's cool and what's not cool and I think that you know as things become more systematic and more processed and you have all of these metrics that are applied at earlier and earlier levels of how to get into grad school and you're in grad school how many papers you need and who you need to work for and what postdoc you need to get I think that's really eroding the creative thought of a lot of our students and and that's a problem and it would be nice to build in some mechanisms to just sort of reinvigorate sort of a curiosity that doesn't have as many consequences if it doesn't pan out in their CV. So if there were ways to sort of do that you know reintroduce that at the graduate student level I think that would really sort of at least help people preserve some sort of like naive creativity which is really helpful and useful in all discussions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's almost always a change for the better in the cases that I've observed over many years. And because you know you're a little wiser when you pick the second time around. But I will say again that the most enabling thing that could be done in science funding is to just fund the students because a big hurdle for a student is well okay so I want to change labs but does advisor X have funding on their grant? You know the answer is I don't know. You know and if if not then I need to stick with this person that that has money to to pay me. Whereas if you pay the students then you know they can shop around. It would also make it easier for students to collaborate with multiple people because again there's no infighting about this grant or that grant where you're getting the funding from it's the student is paid. You know if your research requires that kind of knowledge and this kind of knowledge you can go to two people and and get what you need there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Elizabeth Read
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think that yeah I I mean I I've always liked that idea.
